Legal_Issue: Whether the citizenship judge correctly applied the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1055 days of presence but lacked evidence for part of the period
Court_Ruling: Citizenship judge's decision was reasonable and based on sufficient evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet 1095-day physical presence requirement in Canada within four years prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Review of citizenship judge's decision by the Federal Court
Credibility_Assessment: Judge not convinced beyond a reasonable doubt
Application_Basis: Residency calculation over four-year period preceding application
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation supporting days of physical presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicant must accumulate at least 1095 days of residence in Canada during the four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to prove required days of physical presence
Outcome: Original rejection of citizenship application upheld
Cause_Description: Applicant did not meet the residency requirement due to insufficient evidence of physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Judge found evidence inconclusive regarding claimed days of residence
Evidence_Issues: Lack of verifiable documentation for part of claimed residency period
Decision_Rationale: Decision was reasonable; burden of proof not met by applicant
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Incomplete evidence for claimed 1055 days of presence
